I am Inam Ullah Khan, a data science student passionate about education technology. You can explore more of my work on GitHub or email me at [inamm911@gmail.com].
This site presents Public Perceptions of AI on Education, a data project that analyzes a 2023 survey of 1,200 students to uncover attitudes toward AI tools in the classroom. All code and cleaned data live in the project repository: https://github.com/inammarwat/ai-perceptions-education.
This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp.

title: Public Perceptions of AI on Education
text: How do students perceive the role of artificial intelligence in education, and what divides their trust versus skepticism? This project uses data from a 2023 Kaggle survey conducted by Gianina Maria Petrascu, which gathered responses from over 1,200 students worldwide about their experiences and opinions on AI in education. After removing incomplete responses and cleaning column names, I used R to explore how students’ trust in AI (Y) varies by academic background, age, and gender (X), with a focus on attitudes toward AI grading, fairness, and teacher replacement. The analysis reveals that 65% of students believe AI improves learning efficiency, yet 40% are concerned it may eventually replace human teachers. Trust levels also differ by field of study—STEM students are twice as likely as their humanities peers to trust AI for grading. Additionally, 30% of students express concern about potential bias in AI-driven evaluations. Students are optimistic about AI’s potential in education, but concerns about fairness, bias, and teacher replacement remain major barriers to full acceptance.
